chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Any reform should strengthen public legitimacy by making presidential outcomes track the broad national will while keeping states responsible for running elections and certifying results. A workable compromise is to curb winner‑take‑all incentives by encouraging proportional or multi‑district elector allocation, while allowing a carefully designed interstate popular‑vote agreement as a backstop once participation is sufficiently broad. Whichever route is chosen should be paired with binding elector rules, consistent baseline protections for access and administration, and auditable paper records with routine, transparent post‑election checks so close results are resolved predictably rather than politically.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should keep state-run elections and the constitutional role of states while making each lawful vote carry more comparable weight by moving away from winner-take-all elector allocation toward proportional or district-based methods, and—if there is broad bipartisan support—using an interstate National Popular Vote compact as a transition option. Any change should bind electors to certified results and be paired with uniform, nonpartisan national baselines for ballot access and counting, paper-backed records, transparent recount triggers, and routine post-election audits. Phasing reforms in with clear rules and public education can reduce swing-state distortion, encourage nationwide coalition-building, and strengthen confidence in outcomes.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Any reform should protect the states’ role in running elections while making the presidential outcome track the will of voters more closely and reducing the outsized power of a few swing states. A broad, phased compromise is to end winner-take-all by moving to proportional (or district-based) elector allocation and/or a National Popular Vote interstate compact that activates only after a large, bipartisan group of states joins. To build trust across parties, pair changes with clear rules that bind electors to certified results, paper-backed ballots, routine audits, and transparent recount triggers, and allow ranked-choice voting where states choose to reduce spoiler effects and encourage coalition-building.
